narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about how programs can attempt to explain their outputs, and why thats necessary for the future of automation/ai.
It outlined the very qualitative, often irrational process of decision making and showed how to make systems for decision making through different methods.

This was a great course mixing philosophy/social science and computer science. I found most of the topics and speakers very interesting and I walked away with a better framework for designing algorithms that make good decisions, as well as how to quantify those things.
Finance intersecting with CS (Economic Decision Making), Goal-based Decision Making, Monte Carlo simulations, Python
I feel as if I have a better grasp on the overall decision making process one undergoes.
design of decision system
Nothing.
Automated Decision Systems: some practical topics and methods
I learned a lot about building an automated decision system
Automated Decision Systems
Decision System
Good
Different types of automated decision processes and the things to consider while implementing them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great programming assignments and interesting lectures.

I think some of the assignments could be refined to provide a little more structure, while still being mainly open ended. I also would love to have the term project be a bit more involved and have a wider scope. Also an emphasis on topics outside of the ones discussed could make the course more well rounded. I envision a introductory week discussing the philosophy of decision making, a methods week discussing different numerical measurements to quantify things (maybe some light econometrics), and then diving into the topics so everyone has a good, similar base to work off.

Strengths - Guest lectures. Fascinating guest lecturers ranging from various industries and companies such as Citadel and Meta. Homework were open-ended and allowed for creativity 
Weakness - More feedback on homework assignments. More homework assignments, we only had 3

I think that some of the elements of the course feel disconnected to other parts of it. For instance, I'm not entirely sure how the final lecture connected to the cognitive science of decision making.
I learnt about automated decision systems and simulations etc
Interesting topics and assignments
This course focused on a very intersting subject and is overall pretty good.
very interesting and comprehensive from computer to AI to finance
Not much challenge
Love the assignments, they are interesting and are closely related to topics discussed in class.
Good

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
No. The assignment evaluation criteria is overly strict. TA is mean.
RUN.
Yes, it was a great course with thought provoking assignments and interesting lectures.

I would recommend this course to students who are looking for a 5th class. The workload is pretty light and the content can be interesting at some points. The biggest selling point of this class is the guest lectures where you learn decision systems in various industries. There were only 3 homework and a paper in terms of assignments.
No I took it as a free elective but it was awful
Yes
Yes I would if they are interested
Yes. This course is a very interesting mix between computer science, economical science, and cognitive science, with a blend of machine learning.

yes
great application course
No
Good
Yes if you are interested in financial decision processes since the professor knows a lot about the field.
